results.title: The Story of Seabiscuit = Pride of Kentucky
results.creator_credit: David Butler, William Jacobs and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Irishman Shawn O’Hara (Barry Fitzgerald), a horse trainer with the gift of being able to tell whether a yearling is going to be a winner or not, arrives in Paris, Kentucky, with his niece, Margaret (Shirley Temple) to take up a position at Millford Farms. He is drawn to a horse called Seabiscuit which initially no-one else credits with winning. At the same time a romance slowly blossoms between his niece and jockey Ted Knowles (Lon McCallister). Margaret is reticent at falling in love with a jockey however as she has already lost her brother, also a jockey, when he fell to his death while riding one of Shawn’s horses. The incident caused uncle and niece to flee their native Ireland. Written by John Taintor Foote. Music by David Buttolph. Filmed in Technicolor.

results.title: The Fabulous Baker boys
results.creator_credit: Steve Kloves, Mark Rosenberg, Paula Weinstein, Gladden Entertainment and Mirage Enterprises
results.brief_description: The Baker brothers, Frank and Jack, have been playing together for thirty-one years, as piano accompanists, in an array of bars and nightclubs. In the throes of a dead-end career, the cynical Jack is particularly embittered by their lack of success and thwarted dreams of glory that has resulted in a slew of bad gigs at sleazy dives. Frank, a responsible father of two who worries for their finances, is willing to take any gig for a buck. But Jack is resentful of Frank’s passivity and inability to defend his honour or art. Increasingly unemployable, the brothers hire a singer to spruce up their act - and Susie Diamond, ballsy, rough, lower class but talented, transforms them into a classy act. The alluring presence of the sexy Susie creates tensions for the brothers who are forced to address the inequities and rivalry that mars their relationship. Although the formula of the outsider who upsets the dynamics of a long-standing show-biz relationship has been used frequently in cinema, “The Fabulous Baker boys” still engages and entertains, greatly assisted by the stellar performances of the leads, Jeff and Beau Bridges and Michelle Pfeiffer and an array of sultry tunes.

results.title: The Little shop of horrors [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Roger Corman, American International Pictures (AIP) and Filmgroup
results.brief_description: Originally a film directed by Roger Corman and shot in two days in 1960, then a musical play extravaganza on Broadway in 1982, and finally a multimillion dollar allstar film musical in 1986, “Little shop of horrors,” with its quirkiness, comedy and wonderful satire has developed quite a cult following over the decades. This original version features Jonathan Haze as the nerdy Seymour Krelborn who works in the florist shop near Skid Row, Mel Welles as Mushnik his boss, and Jackie Joseph as Audrey, the shop assistant and woman Seymour secretly desires. When Seymour buys a small exotic plant which suddenly appeared after an eclipse of the sun, strange things begin to happen. Audrey II (Seymour’s name for the plant) takes on a personality of its own and develops quite a unique appetite, wanting to be continually fed, not with plant food, but with blood, and the more it is fed, the bigger Audrey II becomes. This monster plant has an insatiable appetite and the dilemma for Seymour is what can he do about it. Features a cameo by Jack Nicholson in his first motion picture performance as the demented dentist. The legendary Roger Corman made this movie in days and it has more laughs than most big budget films.

results.title: It's a wonderful life [DVD]
results.brief_description: The philanthropic director of a small savings and loan association on the verge of bankruptcy in a small American town thinks he is a failure and contemplates suicide. His guardian angel attempts to convince him that his life has been far from worthless. A comedy-drama in a fantasy framework which recapitulates Capra’s major themes: the fragility of good and virtue and the ever threatening encroachment of evil. (Awards: nominated for five Oscars, including Best Picture, Best Director and Best Actor).

results.title: The New adventures of Pinocchio
results.creator_credit: Michael Anderson, Harald Reichebner, Jeffrey Sneller, Knut Boesner, Raju Patel, Creativ Berlin Filmpartner GmbH and TM
results.brief_description: Pinocchio (Gabriel Thomson) and best friend Lampwick (Ben Ridgeway) visit the carnival of Madame Flambeau (Udo Kier) and hear of the miracle elixir that she claims will act as the fountain of youth. On returning home and finding his father Gepetto (Martin Landau) exhausted and unable to complete producing toys, Pinocchio and Lampwick return to the carnival to get some of the elixir. Unbeknownst to Pinocchio, Flambeau knows about the puppet boy’s past and wanting to make him part of the show, produces a “special” potion. The effects of the elixir aren’t as expected and Gepetto and Lampwick are turned into wood. Having agreed to work for Flambeau until the price of the elixir is payed off, Pinocchio and his father are forced to work as an act in the show until they can think of a way to reverse the spell. Set in Luxembourg and featuring puppets created by the Jim Henson Group, “The New adventures of Pinocchio” should appeal to adults and children alike.

results.title: Going all the way
results.creator_credit: Mark Pellington, Sigurjon Sighvatsson, Tom Gorai, Lakeshore Entertainment and PolyGram Filmed Entertainment
results.brief_description: Set in 1954, post-Korean War, “Going all the way” examines the personal choices of two men, both at crossroads, following discharge from the army. Sonny Burns is self-conscious, shy, sexually inexperienced and in awe of his new friend Gunner Casselman who is confident with women, but questioning his former frat-boy ways after experiencing a cultural awakening in Japan. These two men face choices that will affect them for the rest of their lives when they return to their hometown of Indianapolis but find dissatisfaction with their lot. For his part, Sonny is drawn to the sexually lascivious Gail despite his engagement to girl-next door Buddy. Casselman, who becomes interested in modernist art and is drawn to the concepts of Zen Buddhism, is attracted to an independent Jewish girl, despite the anti-Semitic ranting of his over-affectionate mother. As a coming-of-age drama “Going all the way” plods a fairly predictable path but manages some impressive flourishes, in particular its 1950s aesthetic, ably captured by cinematographer Bobby Bukowsk, and the performances of Jeremy Davies (Secretary, The Million dollar hotel) and Ben Affleck (Pearl Harbour, Good Will Hunting), the latter emitting appropriate charm. Cast includes: Lesley Ann Warren, Rachel Weisz, Rose McGowan, Jill Clayburgh, Amy Locane.

results.title: Fool for love
results.creator_credit: Robert Altman, Menahem Golan, Yoram Globus and Cannon Group
results.brief_description: Robert Altman (The Player, McCabe and Mrs Miller, Nashville, Gosford Park) adapts Sam Shepard’s one room play with mixed results. Shepard plays Eddie, a handsome cowboy drifter who arrives in a depressing New Mexico roadside motel, lugging a trailer and horses. The aim of Eddie’s visit is to be re-united with the voluptuous May, a barmaid at this barren pit stop’s hotel. For her part May is being wooed by another man but is inextricably drawn to Eddie, despite the proven destructive nature of their union. Over the course of the evening she and Eddie argue violently and make up passionately as the heart-rending history of their relationship, replete with flashbacks, unfurls. Harry Dean Stanton plays a barfly whose identity holds a key role to these lovers’ sorrow. “Fool for love” garnered mostly negative reviews and found a very limited audience, regardless of praise for Basinger’s bravura performance. Most decried the device of opening up the play, outside of its claustrophobic one room structure, in favour of a wider locale, which may have robbed it of the intimate tensions generated by the ill-matched pair battling it out in a confined space. But despite this the incendiary relationship between the principal characters is astutely portrayed, achieving a suitably tragic tone within a desolate setting.

results.title: Tango
results.creator_credit: Carlos Saura, Carlos L. Mentasti, Juan Carlos Codazzi, Luis Scalella, Adela Pictures, Alma Ata International Pictures, Argentina Sono Films, Astrolabio Producciones, Beco Films, Hollywood Partners, Pandora Cinema, Saura Films and Terraplen Producciones
results.brief_description: This Argentinian/Spanish co-production is a dance film within a dance film which blurs the lines between rehearsal, real life and performance. Set in Buenos Aires, the film’s slender plot centres on the creative processes of a womanising, middle-aged director who, whilst recovering from a marriage breakup, decides to make a musical centred on the tango. Bearing a close resemblance to the protagonist in Fellini’s “8 1/2” the director dwells on his childhood memories, middle-aged regret and wounded heart as he prepares his film. With only the thinnest of narrative threads linking scenes and moments together, the film relies far more heavily on colour, movement and music than on dialogue or characterisation. The bulk of the film is devoted to expertly-choreographed performances which explore both the fictional director’s personal demons and moments in Argentinian history. Stunningly photographed by Vittorio Storaro. Cast: Miguel Angel Sola, Cecilia Narova, Mia Maestro, Juan Carlos Copes, Carlos Rivarola. In Spanish with English subtitles.

results.title: Nadja
results.creator_credit: Michael Almereyda, Amy Hobby, Mary Sweeney and Kino Link Company
results.brief_description: Revisiting the vampire legend director/writer Michael Almereyda creates a modern day setting for several sexy undead creatures of the night. Elina Lowensohn plays the title role - a New York based vampire who is celebrating the demise of her father, and is hoping that her new life will encompass the attractive Lucy. Unfortunately Lucy is married to the nephew of a vampire hunter who is hell-bent on conquering Nadja. Aesthetically the film is an alluring mix of 35 mm footage and black-and-white, low-budget Pixelvision video. As an art film, the form is impressive but the narrative wanes at key moments, leaving an overall sense of a film that wavers inconsistently between a surrealist Lynchian vision and the deadpan humour of a Hal Hartley.

As an art film, the form is impressive but the narrative wanes at key moments, leaving an overall sense of a film that wavers inconsistently between a surrealist Lynchian vision and the deadpan humour of a Hal Hartley.

results.title: Hidden agenda
results.creator_credit: Ken Loach, Eric Fellner and Hemdale Film Corporation
results.brief_description: American lawyer Paul Sullivan (Brad Dourif), is working in Northern Ireland as part of a group similar to Amnesty International, when he is assassinated by police who claimed that he failed to stop at a road block and was in the company of a suspected terrorist. His fiancee and fellow activist Ingrid Jessner (Frances McDormand) is left shattered. She has a glimmer of hope that justice will prevail after the arrival of British policeman Paul Kerrigan (Brian Cox) who has been sent to investigate the circumstances surrounding the death, and the actions of the three men implicated in the deaths: members of the undercover anti terrorist squad, the SSU (Special Support Unit). Kerrigan is initially fearless in his investigation, refusing the protection offered to him by the RUC in an effort to remain impartial to people who may be involved. However, when he uncovers a conspiracy to destabilize the previous Labour government, he is faced with the consequences of disclosing the information. Ken Loach based his film on the Stalker affair - the real life case of senior police official John Stalker, assigned to investigate a killing by British security officials. Stalker was removed from the case amidst speculations that the then Thatcher government was unhappy with his findings. Screenplay by Jim Allen.
